oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Centennial Exposition Season Ticket
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Tickets
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Season ticket booklet for admission to the Tennessee Centennial Expostition of 1897. The cover has an image of a shield surrounded by a wreath and ribbon. The words "Tennessee Centennial Nashville, Tenn." appear on the shield and the ribbon above it reads "May 1st 1897 to Oct. 31st 1897." The number "2112" is printed in the center of the cover, and there are two names written on the bottom: Miss Mary L. Harris, the ticket holder; and E. C. Lewis, Director General of the Exposition.

A visitor to the Tennessee Centennial Exposition had the option of buying an admission ticket at the exposition's gate or purchasing a booklet of coupons allowing repeated admissions. A photograph of the ticket holder, on the inside of the booklet, was; used for identification purposes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Centennial Exposition printed advertisement
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Advertisements; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Festivals; Fairs; Eagles; Horses; Presidents; Government officials; Heads of state; Capitols; Seals (Insignia)
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Printed advertisement for the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, May 1 to October 31, 1897. Includes inset views of Pres. William J. McKinley, Vice President Garret A. Hobart, the White House and the U.S. Capitol building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States. Bureau of Engraving and Printing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: United States. Bureau of Engraving and Printing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee Centennial Exposition was held in Nashville in 1897 to celebrate Tennessee's 100th anniversary of statehood. This industrial exposition featured exhibits on agriculture, commerce, transportation, culture, machinery, education, and more.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Government Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Events; Fairs; Commemorations; Flags; Domes
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Angled view of the U.S. Government Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The building stood close to the main entrance of the grounds near Lake Katherine. The building, with classical style architecture, had the form of a cross. The center was intended to resemble in general appearance the dome of the newly constructed Library of Congress in Washington. Flags were mounted on each corner of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The purpose of the Government Building was to exemplify the workings of the United States Government. Ten different departments, such as the War and Treasury Departments, displayed exhibits which were brought to the building by railroad cars of the Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway Company. The Railway Company had to extend its tracks up to the east end of the building for unloading purposes.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Terminal Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Fairs; Festivals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Terminal Building at the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition. The image features a front and side view of the building. The top of the building carries the lettering "Railway Exhibits." The grounds clearly contain decorative fountains and statuary as well as distinctive plantings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Terminal Station of the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition marks the entrance of the Nashville, Chattanooga & St. Louis Railway onto the grounds of the Centennial City. This one hundred foot square building allowed railroad lines to highlight the vegetable and mineral products of the soils that bordered their routes. The states of Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, and Georgia were represented. J. B. Killebrew was responsible for the exhibit staged by the Nashville, Chattanooga & St. Louis Railway. Indian and war relics took their place alongside the various agricultural and mineral displays. The tobacco exhibit within these walls warranted particular attention.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pythian Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Fairs; Festivals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Pythian Building, Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition. The building was situated on Lake Watauga. The picture shows a man rowing a gondola near a small bridge on the lake. Behind the Pythian Building can be seen the Parthenon and to either side large buildings which tend to dwarf the smaller building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Pythian Building was erected by members of the order of the Knights of Pythias, a secret and fraternal order whose Nashville members erected the building as a resting place and social gathering to be used during the Centennial. The building was modeled after Monticello, the home of President Thomas Jefferson.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chute at Vanity Fair
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries; Amusement rides; Water slides
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Chute located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee.

The Chute was a water ride in which the passenger boarded a boat that slid down a steep incline and splashed into the lake below, covering onlookers with a spray of water. The attraction was located at the highest point in the park. The pool of water was only 30 inches deep. A ride on the Chute cost 10 cents.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Electric Fountain
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries; Sculpture; Fountains
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Electric Fountain located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee.
The Electric Fountain, created by sculptor Morretti, was powered by electricity and was lit at night. It was located near the entrance to the Woman's Building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lake Katherine
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries; Lakes & ponds; Waterwheels; Water power; Dams
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of Lake Katherine, located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee.

Lake Katherine was named after "Bonnie Kate" Sevier, the second wife of Tennessee's first Governor, John Sevier. The dam and waterwheel are shown at the center of the photograph. The waterwheel came from an area near Nashville called the Leatherwoods. A Lithia water stand was just beyond the dam, and the Minerals and Forestry Building stood to the left.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rialto Bridge across Lake Watauga
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries; Lakes & ponds; Pedestrian bridges
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Rialto Bridge across Lake Watauga located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee. Passing under the bridge is a gondola.

The Rialto Bridge across Lake Watauga connected the terminus of Capital Avenue with the east entrance to the Parthenon. The Rialto housed shops where fairgoers could purchase a variety of Centennial souvenirs. The bridge was illuminated at night with numerous incandescent lamps.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: W. Spain's Palace of Illusions and Mirrors
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Midways; Mirrors; Entertainment; Optical illusions; Celebrations; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Festivals; Fairs; Forensic photographs
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of the castle-like structure of W. Spain's Palace of Illusions and Mirror Maze, featured in the Vanity Fair area of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, 1897. A number of men and women are standing at the entrance area, surrounded by signs promoting the attractions.

This building was located within Vanity Fair, the amusement section of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, at the western corner of the park. The structure housed two distinct exhibitions which could both be viewed for the admission price of 25 cents. The image was found in Tennessee Supreme Court case J.B. Ellison vs. W.P. Spain as Exhibit No. 1 to the deposition of C.G. Walden.

Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A black and white portrait of J.W. Thomas. Underneath is his signature and two sets of dates: "Mar.30-1880 to June 30-1880; Sept. 10-1884 to Feb.12-1906."
J. W. Thomas
J.W. Thomas served as President of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A color aerial view drawing of the Tennessee Centennial of 1897 showing the various buildings, paths, and attractions. The upper left corner of the cover has a black-and-white photograph of Mrs. Van Leer Kirkman, President of the Woman's Board of the Exposition. A handwritten notation, in ink, is near the top of the cover: "June 25, 1897."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Minerals & Forestry Building

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Fairs; Festivals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and side view of the Minerals & Forestry Building, Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition. The Roman-Doric architectural style is clearly shown. In the foreground can be seen Lake Watauga with a small boat on the water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This was one of the larger builldings at the Exposition, containing a total of 76,888 square feet. It proved to be one of the favorite exhibits. Native and imported woods were displayed along with minerals from various states. It was believed that this building was similar in style to "Arlington," the Arlington, Virginia, home of General Robert E. Lee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: History Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Festivals; Fairs; Exhibition buildings
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the History Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Shows the six majestic columns at the front of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiles, Marvin Willard, ca. 1883-1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The History Building was divided into five compartments. The central and largest room was set apart for History and Antiquities; another room was for the use of the Confederate Veterans; one room for the Grand Army of the Republic; one for the Colonial Dames and Daughters of the American Revolution; and the last room was for miscellaneous purposes. The History Building stood near the Parthenon.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee Centennial Ride
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Festivals; Fairs; Amusement rides; Exhibition buildings
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph featuring the Giant See-Saw, a very popular attraction located in the midway of Vanity Fair at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. This shot taken from a nearby hill shows Spain's Palace of Illusions (Mirror Maze) on the left and the Old Vienna Restaurant on the right. The cabins were transported from East Tennessee and were equipped with a functioning moonshine still. Other Centennial buildings that appear in the background are the Hygiene and Education Building, the Commerce Building, a bit of the Parthenon, and in the far distance appears the Memphis Building (Pyramid of Cheops). The Gerst Brewing Company maintained a number of stations on the premises. The advertisement appearing in the image credits them with the best beer and the best meals on the grounds.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiles, Marvin Willard, ca. 1883-1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This steel attraction was invented by a Nashville company and had the capacity to hoist twenty people in each of its two cars to an excess of 208 feet. The cost of the first ride on the See-Saw was twenty-five cents; additional rides were a dime.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Negro Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); African Americans -- History -- Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Negro Building, located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee. In front of the building is Lake Watauga.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiles, Marvin Willard, ca. 1883-1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The ornate Spanish Renaissance-style architecture was used in the design of the Negro Building. The cornerestone was laid on March 13, 1897. The orator of the day was Professor W. H. Council, principal of the Agricultural and Mechanical College for Negroes in Normal, Alabama. There were over 300 exhibitions from 85 cities with displays which included information on education, science, technology, banking, and art. Fisk University's exhibit showed the possibilities for African Americans in higher education. Tuskegee Institute in Alabama was represented by Booker T. Washington, who was special guest on Emancipation Day, September 22.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Illinois Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Exhibition buildings; Festivals; Fairs; Anniversaries
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Illinois Building, located at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville, Tennessee. In the foreground is a lake.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wiles, Marvin Willard, ca. 1883-1957
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Illinois Building was erected by the State of Illinois as a miniature reproduction of the Administration building at the Chicago World's Fair. It was one-sixth the size of the original, and was used as a headquarters for Illinois visitors. The building was located at the end of Capitol Avenue, and was in view of the Rialto and the Parthenon. The Illinois Legislature donated $60,000 for the construction of the building. Surrounding the building was statuary representing elements of nature and man's creative spirit.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Proclamations; Governors
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Turney, Peter, 1827-1903
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Proclamation of Tennessee Governor Peter Turney, dated May 28, 1896, designating the observance of June 1st and 2nd as official state holidays commemorating the anniversary of Tennessee's admission into the Union.
Peter Turney served as Governor of Tennessee from 1893 to 1897.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Presbyterian Day Program of the Tennessee Exposition, 1897
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Programs
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover of a program announcing "Presbyterian Day" on October 28, 1897, at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The center of the program features an image of a log cabin, and each corner of the program has the names of persons associated with the formation of Presbyterianism in early Tennessee. All the text and artwork is done in blue.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The four persons named on the front of the program were the "pioneers" of Presbyterianism in early Tennessee, including Rev. Charles Cummings (ca. 1746-1812) and Rev. Samuel Doak (1749-after 1818).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Education Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Events; Fairs; Anniversaries; Commemorations
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of the Hygiene and Education Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The top of the Giant See-Saw may be seen in the top left corner of the photograph.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Hygiene and Education building had four identical fronts with four columns each. The ornamentation on each front varied with statuary on Oratory, Philosophy, History, Science, and Medicine. The west entrance of the building was ornamented with flags from several nations. One section of the building was dedicated to the progress of higher education. In the northwest corner of the building, the University of Tennessee at Knoxville had three x-ray machines on display. Additionally, there was a fully operational laboratory, a collection of surgical and medical instruments, and an exhibit of the latest modern methods of sanitary plumbing.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dormitories of Vanderbilt University pamphlet

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Dormitories; Public accommodation facilities
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Vanderbilt University
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pamphlet of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition containing information for accommodations at dormitories at Vanderbilt University in Nashville. The pamphlet has a photograph of the Parthenon on the front and states that accommodations are available from June 20 to September 10. The pamphlet features descriptions of the various dormitories on the campus.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Westside Clubhouse (Administration) Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Clubhouses; Arbors (Bowers); Gardens
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mounted black and white photograph of an arbor at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. In the background is a view of the Westside Clubhouse for visitors.

The Westside Clubhouse was originally constructed for the West Side Park. It was converted to a restaurant at the opening of the exposition. At one point the house was known as the "Administration" building. The area was surrounded by a park, including an arbor designed by Currey and Company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Auditorium and Commerce Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibit booths; Auditoriums; Concert halls; Social & civic facilities
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mounted black and white photograph of the Auditorium and the Commerce Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition.

The Auditorium was the site of a large number of concerts and ceremonies during the Exposition. The bells were played on special occasions, such as Opening Day, Independence Day and Ohio Day when President William McKinley came to visit. The Auditorium seated over 6,000 people. Crowds heard concerts performed by Guston Fischer's Band, Victor Herbert's 24th New York Regimental Band, and others. Today the bells hang in the Tulip Street Methodist Church in Nashville. This building was considered by many to be the "least pretty" of all the buildings. The Commerce Building housed exhibits from Nashville businesses as well as from countries throughout the world. Included in the building were exhibits sponsored by William Gerst Brewing Company, Marshall and Bruce Company, Gray-Dudley Hardware Company, and Phillips and Buttorff Manufacturing Company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Machinery Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibit booths; Machinery; Engine rooms
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small black and white photograph of the Machinery Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition.

The Machinery Building was of Greek-Doric style architecture and displayed machinery of every variety. Two innovations displayed were a round-bale cotton press and an automatic gear-cutting machine. The engines inside the building furnished all the power to operate every electric light, as well as the arc lights on the ground.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Parthenon
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Buildings; Exhibition buildings; Galleries & museums; Greek temples; Reproductions
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Parthenon replica building in Nashville, Tennessee.

The replica of the Parthenon was the Nashville-Davidson County building. The decision was made to build the Parthenon because Nashville was known as "The Athens of the South." During the Exposition it housed nearly 1,200 pieces of artwork and sculpture from all over the world. The Parthenon was situated in the center of the Exposition grounds. The pedestal sculptures beneath the roofline depicted the contest between Poseidon and Athena. The west pediment sculptures of the ancient Parthenon were reproduced by sculptor George Zolnay at both ends of the building and were made of plaster. The Parthenon is the only structure that remains of all the Exposition buildings. It was reconstructed in the 1920s, and became a permanent structure.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Transportation Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Gazebos
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Angled view of the Transportation Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Constructed in the Italian Renaissance style, the building had a very simplistic appearance. A gazebo stands in the forefront.

The Transportation Building was located in the northwestern section of the park near the Railway exhibits and Terminal Station Building. The building had a frontage of four hundred feet and a depth of one hundred and twenty-five feet. Railroad tracks ran throughout the building, and doors at the north end could admit trains and engines. The interior had displays of railway trains, carriages, wagons, bicycles, and all types of rolling stock.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woman's Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Columns
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of the Woman's Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The building was somewhat modeled after Andrew Jackson's home, the Hermitage. In addition, the building also had features of Grecian architecture. Eight massive columns supported the roof, on top of which was an observatory. The front steps, each thirty-five feet long, were made of Tennessee marble.

The Woman's Building was designed by Mrs. Sarah Ward-Conley. Visitors could enjoy lunch at the restaurant located in the observatory, buy articles made by women in the salesroom, view inventions made by women in the Patent Room, or take cooking lessons in the model kitchen. The interior of the Woman's Building was decorated with all things considered beautiful, such as inviting colors, Tiffany stained glass, mural decorations, exquisite furnishings, fresh flowers, and silk draperies. The building also included a library made of black walnut and a pink room with pink velvet carpet that housed portrait statues.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Commerce Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibit booths
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Commerce Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition.

The Commerce Building housed exhibits from Nashville's businesses, as well as exhibits from countries throughout the world. Included in the building were exhibits sponsored by such local companies as William Gerst Brewing Company, Marshall and Bruce Company, Gray-Dudley Hardware Company and Phillips and Buttorff Manufacturing Company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Interior view of the library in the Woman's Building of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. In addition to several volumes of books, the room is adorned with furniture, sculpture and an elaborate bas-relief mantel. An electric chandelier hangs from the ceiling.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Parks; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Exhibition buildings; Columns; Construction; Buildings; Architectural elements; Lakes & ponds
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Centennial Park, showing the construction process and a general view of Lake Watauga and Lily Lake. The Auditorium, Parthenon, Flagstaff, Administration Building, Commerce Building, and Transportation Building are pictured. Scaffolding is erected outside the main entrance to the Transportation Building.
The Tennessee Centennial Exposition was held in Nashville in 1897 to celebrate Tennessee's 100th anniversary of statehood.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Agriculture Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Events; Fairs; Anniversaries; Celebrations; Commemorations; Flags; Gondolas; Lakes & ponds; Passengers
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: View of the Agriculture Building across Lake Watauga at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. A passenger-filled gondola is shown on the lake.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Agriculture Building had a large central dome surrounded by six smaller domes. Five of these domes were dedicated to Tennessee's agricultural contributions, including corn, cotton, and tobacco.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Machinery Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Fairs; Festivals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Machinery Building, also called Machinery Hall, at the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition. The architectural style was an example of Greek Doric and served as a perfect complement to the Parthenon, which appeared on the opposite side of Lake Watauga. The foreground of the image features Lake Watauga.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Machinery Building measured 375 x 138 feet and highlighted the genius of mechanical invention. It was a strikingly handsome and massive structure patterned after the Greek Parthenon and the Propylaeum in Munich. The machinery in the building was run by the Corliss engine, which was manufactured in Hamilton, Ohio.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General view of Tennessee Centennial
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Buildings; Exhibition buildings; Celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Events; Fairs; Festivals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This general view of the Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition features the Parthenon and the Memphis Pavilion in the foreground of the image. The Commerce Building, the Education Building and the Giant See-Saw are in the background of the photograph. Lake Watauga occupies the foreground of the image. The prevalence of flags flying, bench seating, and such infrastructure elements as sidewalks, street lamps, and decorative railings and columns on the grounds reveal the mammoth scale of this undertaking for the State of Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition was held in the 200-acre West Side Park of Nashville and ran from May 1, 1897 to October 30, 1897. The event honored the 100th year of statehood for Tennessee; the celebration was delayed one year due to financing problems and the unfinished state of some attractions. The site itself was renamed Centennial City and featured thirty-five major structures on its grounds. The location had served as the historic site for the mustering of troops for the War of 1812, the Mexican War, and the Civil War before becoming the Old Fair Grounds and a harness racing park.

Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An exterior view of the Children's Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, which was located beside the Gourd Arbor. The building was a two-story structure with Rococo style architecture.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Everything of interest to children was housed in the Children's Building. Throughout the Exposition a kindergarten class was held as well as a series of entertainments for children.

The booklet contains information regarding the Woman's Board and Woman's Building as well as pictures. Cover includes an illustration of the Women's Department medal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mrs. Van Leer Kirkman served as President of the Woman's Board. The Board consisted of one hundred women who were assisted by three hundred and twenty women commissioners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bandstand near the Rialto
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Fairs; Gazebos; Bands; Bandstands
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph showing the Tennessee Centennial Exposition bandstand. In the background is the Rialto.
The bandstand was used for outdoor concerts at the exposition. Outdoor music, along with military orchestras, was very popular during the late 19th century.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Red Men's Tepee
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Exhibitions; Fairs; Centennial celebrations; Exhibition buildings; Commemorations; Historical reenactments; Indigenous peoples; Fraternal organizations; Charitable organizations; Tipis
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the "Red Men's Tepee." Shows a building constructed in the form of a tepee for the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. A small crowd stands at the entrance.

The "Red Men's Tepee" was the headquarters of the Improved Order of Red Men. Its members dressed like "Indians," complete with war paint and feathers. They practiced "Indian" customs and even played the role of the foes of Custer and the 7th Cavalry in the re-creation of the Battle of Little Big Horn during military week in August 1897.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Outdoor Display of Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Fairs; Railroads; Forge shops; Foundries; Metallurgical industry; Smelters
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph showing the outdoor display of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Pictured are representations of pioneer chimneys and ore smelters.

This display was located near the Terminal Building and the Agricultural Building. The display attempted too show the early iron ore industry, as well as representations of pioneer times in Tennessee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memphis-Shelby County Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Fairs; Exhibition buildings; Commercialism; Pyramids
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Memphis-Shelby County building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The building is in the shape of a pyramid. Surrounding the building are Egyptian columns.

The Memphis-Shelby County building was modeled after the Cheops Pyramid because of the city of Memphis and its connection to ancient Memphis, Egypt. Inside the pyramid were displays sponsored by the businesses of Memphis exhibiting commerce and industry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gorman & Boone's Arena of Wild and Trained Animals
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Fairs; Exhibition buildings; Circus animals; Circuses & shows; Sideshows; Trained animals
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the front entrance of Gorman & Boone's Arena of Wild and Trained Animals at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. People are standing at the entrance. A carriage is located in the foreground.

Entertainment and amusement were a part of great fairs and expositions. At the Tennessee Centennial, various shows from all parts of the world were centered in one street called "Vanity Fair." This area provided the fairgoer with a choice of many strange and exotic entertainments, including the one pictured here. Children especially enjoyed this amusement, with its lions and monkeys.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Fairs; Exhibition buildings; Historical reenactments; Circular buildings
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Gettysburg, Battle of, Gettysburg, Pa., 1863
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white photograph of the Cyclorama of the Battle of Gettysburg at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Shows the front entrance of the building. The building was a circular structure.

Inside the circular walls of the Cyclorama was a painting which depicted the famous charge of Gen. Pickett's Division at the stone wall on the 3rd day of the Battle of Gettysburg. This work is said to have required 16 months of labor by 13 artists. Seven tons of paint were used. The exhibit was popular with Union and Confederate veterans alike and contained many relics from the Civil War.

Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of the Auditorium at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, which had Colonial style architecture. It had a one-hundred and forty foot high square tower and four porticoes on the corners of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calvert Bros. & Taylor
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Auditorium was used to hold large meetings, events, and concerts accommodating up to six thousand people. The preliminary inaugural exercises were held in the Auditorium on June 1, 1896, where the history of Tennessee was reviewed for the previous one hundred years.

The full text of the front cover reads "Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition opens at Nashville May 1st 1897 and continues six months. The Parthenon Art building of Exposition--A fireproof structure."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: J. W. Thomas Address
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Public speaking; Exhibitions; Souvenirs
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Thomas, J. W. (John Wilson), 1830-1906
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three-page souvenir transcript of an address by J.W. Thomas, President of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, delivered at the opening of the exposition on May 1, 1897. Thomas proclaimed that the event was to celebrate the state's past and present and inspire hope for the future. He also noted dollar amounts contributed to the affair by federal, state, and local governments. Thomas called on God to bless the exhibition.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas was president of the Nashville, Chattanooga & St. Louis Railway.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Exhibitions; Anniversaries; Fairs; Commemorations; Buildings; Kindergartens; Children; Envelopes
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A postal envelope addressed to Prof. A.H. Merrill of Vanderbilt University. In the left corner of the envelope is a sketch of the Children's Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. Included is a receipt for tuition at the model kindergarten.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Children's Building was located near the Woman's Building. It featured playgrounds and a deer petting zoo. Also, a model kindergarten was located in the building. Professor W.T. Davis, Miss Duncan and Mrs. McHenry taught the kindergarten in which; classes were held throughout the six months of the Exposition.

Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.); Thomas, J. W. (John Wilson), 1830-1906
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A souvenir ticket of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The ticket commemorates J.W. Thomas Day held on Thursday, October 28, 1897. The front side of the ticket includes a picture of J.W. Thomas and bears the signature of Director General E. C. Lewis. The reverse side of the ticket contains an image of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition seal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: J. W. Thomas and Eugene C. Lewis were chief officers of the Nashville, Chattanooga, and St. Louis Railway. During the Exposition, J. W. Thomas served as President and Eugene C. Lewis as Director General.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Clothing & dress
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-painted sash in honor of Mrs. William McKinley's visit to the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The sash reads "Woman's Department, Tennessee Centennial, In honor of Mrs. McKinley, June 12 1897." The name tag reads "Miss Mary Bass."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900

Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Stereograph showing the back of a statue depicting Virtue at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition. The statue is on the edge of a lily pond and stands beneath a waterfall.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Lingley, B. L.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Centennial celebrations; Anniversaries; Commemorations; Fairs; Exhibitions; Programs; Rites & ceremonies
Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition (1897 : Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A 4-page program providing details of the opening day of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition on May 1, 1897. Included in the program are the names of speakers as well as congratulatory telegrams from prominent politicians and businessmen.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Centennial and International Exposition Collection, 1895-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The official opening of the Exposition took place on May 1, 1897. President William McKinley pressed a button in the White House in Washington D.C. that started an electrical relay that ran down through Virginia, to North Carolina, and across Tennessee; to Nashville that fired a cannon, setting the machinery into motion and opening the gates to the Exposition.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: House Resolution 161 introduced by Mr. Washington to aid and encourage the holding of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition at Nashville in the year 1896 and making an appropriation for it.
